newsitem.title: USA: FTC votes 3-2 to bar RJR from using Joe Camel ads.
newsitem.headline: FTC votes 3-2 to bar RJR from using Joe Camel ads.

text.p: The Federal Trade Commission said it voted 3-2 Wednesday to seek an order barring R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. from using its "Joe Camel" campaign in ads accessible to children.
In a statement, the regulatory agency said it would seek to have the company conduct a public education campaign discouraging young people from smoking.

The FTC said the Joe Camel campaign was "successful in appealing to many children and adolescents under 18." They also said the campaign "induced many young people to begin smoking or to continue smoking cigarettes and as a result caused significant injury to their health and safety."
The FTC's complaint will be heard before an administrative law judge. The FTC also warned that it may consider further penalties against the company.
"The commission also may order further relief, such as corrective advertising or other affirmative disclosures, after the trial on the case has concluded," the statement said.
R.J. Reynolds, a unit of RJR Nabisco Holding Corp., said Wednesday the FTC's complaint was unwarranted and the agency's lawsuit would not prevail.
